pageProps.contentHtml:
Jensen's formula, meromorphic functions

Let fff be a non-constant meromorphic function in the complex plane. Assume that if fff has a pole at the point z∈Cz \in \Cz∈C, then zzz is of the form nπn\pinπ with integer n∈Zn \in \Zn∈Z. Assume that for all non-real zzz we have the estimate

∣f(z)∣≤(1+∣Im⁡z∣−1)e−Im⁡z.\abs{f\p{z}} \leq \p{1 + \abs{\Im{z}}^{-1}}e^{-\Im{z}}.∣f(z)∣≤(1+∣Imz∣−1)e−Imz.

Prove that for every integer n∈Zn \in \Zn∈Z, fff has a pole at the point nπn\pinπ.
Solution.

Suppose fff has a pole at nπn\pinπ and let ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0. Then for z=nπ+iεz = n\pi + i\epsilonz=nπ+iε,

∣(z−nπ)f(z)∣≤(∣z−nπ∣+∣z−nπ∣∣Im⁡z∣)e−Im⁡z=(ε+1)e−ε.\begin{aligned} \abs{\p{z - n\pi}f\p{z}} &\leq \p{\abs{z - n\pi} + \frac{\abs{z - n\pi}}{\abs{\Im{z}}}}e^{-\Im{z}} \\ &= \p{\epsilon + 1}e^{-\epsilon}. \end{aligned}∣(z−nπ)f(z)∣​≤(∣z−nπ∣+∣Imz∣∣z−nπ∣​)e−Imz=(ε+1)e−ε.​

Thus, (z−nπ)f(z)\p{z - n\pi}f\p{z}(z−nπ)f(z) is bounded as ε→0\epsilon \to 0ε→0, so fff must have a simple pole at nπn\pinπ. Indeed, if fff had a pole with higher order, then ∣(z−nπ)f(z)∣\abs{\p{z - n\pi}f\p{z}}∣(z−nπ)f(z)∣ must diverge to ∞\infty∞ from any path.

Let g(z)=f(z)sin⁡zg\p{z} = f\p{z}\sin{z}g(z)=f(z)sinz. Because fff had a simple pole at each nπn\pinπ and sin⁡z\sin{z}sinz has a simple zero at each nπn\pinπ, we have by the factor theorem that sin⁡z=(z−nπ)h(z)\sin{z} = \p{z - n\pi}h\p{z}sinz=(z−nπ)h(z), where hhh is holomorphic near nπn\pinπ. Thus, g(z)=(z−nπ)f(z)h(z)g\p{z} = \p{z - n\pi}f\p{z}h\p{z}g(z)=(z−nπ)f(z)h(z), so ggg is holomorphic at nπn\pinπ. In particular, ggg is entire.

Also notice that by definition,

∣sin⁡z∣≤∣eiz−e−iz2i∣≤e∣z∣+e∣z∣2=e∣z∣,\abs{\sin{z}} \leq \abs{\frac{e^{iz} - e^{-iz}}{2i}} \leq \frac{e^{\abs{z}} + e^{\abs{z}}}{2} = e^{\abs{z}},∣sinz∣≤∣∣​2ieiz−e−iz​∣∣​≤2e∣z∣+e∣z∣​=e∣z∣,

so we have the bound

∣g(z)∣≤1+1∣Im⁡z∣.\abs{g\p{z}} \leq 1 + \frac{1}{\abs{\Im{z}}}.∣g(z)∣≤1+∣Imz∣1​.

We will show that ggg vanishes nowhere. By Jensen's formula, if ggg has zero anywhere, then

12π∫02πlog⁡∣g(Reiθ)∣ dθ≥Alog⁡R\frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \log\abs{g\p{Re^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta \geq A\log{R}2π1​∫02π​log∣∣​g(Reiθ)∣∣​dθ≥AlogR

for AAA large enough, so it suffices to prove that this integral tends to 000. By our previous estimate,

12π∫02πlog⁡∣g(Reiθ)∣ dθ≤12π∫02πlog⁡∣1+1R∣sin⁡θ∣∣ dθ=2π∫0π/2log⁡∣1+1Rsin⁡θ∣ dθ.\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \log\abs{g\p{Re^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta &\leq \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \log\abs{1 + \frac{1}{R\abs{\sin\theta}}} \,\diff\theta \\ &= \frac{2}{\pi} \int_0^{\pi/2} \log\abs{1 + \frac{1}{R\sin\theta}} \,\diff\theta. \end{aligned}2π1​∫02π​log∣∣​g(Reiθ)∣∣​dθ​≤2π1​∫02π​log∣∣​1+R∣sinθ∣1​∣∣​dθ=π2​∫0π/2​log∣∣​1+Rsinθ1​∣∣​dθ.​

The equality comes from periodicity of sin⁡θ\sin\thetasinθ. Write θ=tπ2\theta = \frac{t\pi}{2}θ=2tπ​ for t∈[0,1]t \in \br{0, 1}t∈[0,1] so that by concavity of sin⁡θ\sin\thetasinθ,

sin⁡θ≥tsin⁡π2=t=2θπ.\sin\theta \geq t\sin\frac{\pi}{2} = t = \frac{2\theta}{\pi}.sinθ≥tsin2π​=t=π2θ​.

Since t∈[0,1]t \in \br{0, 1}t∈[0,1] this inequality holds for θ∈[0,π2]\theta \in \br{0, \frac{\pi}{2}}θ∈[0,2π​] and combining this with the change of variables u=1θu = \frac{1}{\theta}u=θ1​ to get

12π∫02πlog⁡∣g(Reiθ)∣ dθ≤2π∫0π/2log⁡∣1+π2Rθ∣ dθ≤2π∫2/π∞1u2log⁡∣1+uπ2R∣ du.\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \log\abs{g\p{Re^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta &\leq \frac{2}{\pi} \int_0^{\pi/2} \log\abs{1 + \frac{\pi}{2R\theta}} \,\diff\theta \\ &\leq \frac{2}{\pi} \int_{2/\pi}^\infty \frac{1}{u^2} \log\abs{1 + \frac{u\pi}{2R}} \,\diff{u}. \end{aligned}2π1​∫02π​log∣∣​g(Reiθ)∣∣​dθ​≤π2​∫0π/2​log∣∣​1+2Rθπ​∣∣​dθ≤π2​∫2/π∞​u21​log∣∣​1+2Ruπ​∣∣​du.​

Finally, notice that for uuu large enough,

1u2log⁡∣1+uπ2R∣≤u1/2u2=1u3/2∈L1([2π,∞)).\frac{1}{u^2} \log\abs{1 + \frac{u\pi}{2R}} \leq \frac{u^{1/2}}{u^2} = \frac{1}{u^{3/2}} \in L^1\p{\pco{\frac{2}{\pi}, \infty}}.u21​log∣∣​1+2Ruπ​∣∣​≤u2u1/2​=u3/21​∈L1([π2​,∞)).

Thus, by dominated convergence,

lim⁡R→∞12π∫02πlog⁡∣g(Reiθ)∣ dθ≤lim⁡R→∞2π∫2/π∞1u2log⁡∣1+uπ2R∣ du=2π∫2/π∞1u2log⁡1 du=0.\begin{aligned} \lim_{R\to\infty} \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \log\abs{g\p{Re^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta &\leq \lim_{R\to\infty} \frac{2}{\pi} \int_{2/\pi}^\infty \frac{1}{u^2} \log\abs{1 + \frac{u\pi}{2R}} \,\diff{u} \\ &= \frac{2}{\pi} \int_{2/\pi}^\infty \frac{1}{u^2} \log{1} \,\diff{u} \\ &= 0. \end{aligned}R→∞lim​2π1​∫02π​log∣∣​g(Reiθ)∣∣​dθ​≤R→∞lim​π2​∫2/π∞​u21​log∣∣​1+2Ruπ​∣∣​du=π2​∫2/π∞​u21​log1du=0.​

Hence, ggg has no zeroes. Because ggg is entire, it follows from Liouville's theorem applied to 1g\frac{1}{g}g1​ that ggg is constant, i.e.,

f(z)sin⁡z=C  ⟹  f(z)=Csin⁡z.f\p{z}\sin{z} = C \implies f\p{z} = \frac{C}{\sin{z}}.f(z)sinz=C⟹f(z)=sinzC​.

As a result, fff has a simple pole at nπn\pinπ for every n∈Zn \in \Zn∈Z, as desired.
